titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Irving and Hela Norman Papers, circa 1920-2010, in the Archives of American Art AAA.normirvi
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 213287

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-05-30T10:30-0400

did.abstract: The papers of Irving and Hela Norman measure 10.0 linear feet and date from circa 1920 to 2010. The papers document the career of painter Irving Norman through biographical material; correspondence with family, friends, curators, art galleries, and museums; writings, exhibition records, personal business records, printed material, personal photographs, and photographs of his artwork. Also found are numerous audio and video interviews of Irving and Hela Norman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Irving and Hela Norman measure 10.0 linear feet and date from circa 1920 to 2010. The papers document the career of painter Irving Norman through biographical material; correspondence with family, friends, curators, art galleries, and museums; writings, exhibition records, personal business records, printed material, personal photographs, and photographs of his artwork. Also found are numerous audio and video interviews of Irving and Hela Norman.

Researchers should note that the collection primarily documents Irving Norman's late career and Hela Norman's work to manage the exhibition and sale of Irving's work after his death. Almost all of the Norman's drawings and personal records were lost in a house and studio fire in December 1988.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Irving and Hela Norman papers, circa 1920-2010. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: A small amount of material was donated by Irving and Hela Norman in 1988-1989. The bulk of the collection was donated in 2011 by Hela Norman via Tom Von Tersch, Trustee.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Irving and Hela Norman papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart in 2013. The collection has been minimally rearranged and retains the existing/original folder titles when possible. All materials have been rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but often staples and other fasteners have not been removed. Materials within folders have not been rearranged.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Also in the Archives of American Art is a videorecording of an interview with Irving Norman, produced by Bay Area Video Coalition, Zeke Richardson and Larry Andrews, in cooperation with the Archives of American Art. The interview was conducted by Michael S. Bell, March 5, 1988.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Additional loaned material, including slides, photographs of artwork, and letters, was returned to Hela Norman in 1990 after microfilming. Loaned material is available on reel 4705 but is not described in the container listing of this finding aid.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 8 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1929-2010 (0.4 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Interviews, circa 1974-2008 (3 linear feet; Box 4-7)
Series 5: Exhibition Records, 1980-2008 (1 linear foot; Box 7-8)
Series 6: Personal Business Records, 1974-2010 (0.8 linear feet; Box 8-9)
Series 7: Printed Material, 1940s-2000s (0.3 linear feet; Box 9)
Series 8: Photographs, circa 1920-2010 (1.4 linear feet; Box 9-10)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Irving Norman (1906-1989) was a social surrealist painter in San Francisco, Calif. He married Hela Bohlen (1927-2010) in 1955.

Norman was born Irving Noachowitz in Vilna, Russia in 1906. He emigrated to the United States in 1923 and worked in a barber shop in Monticello, New York. In 1934 he moved to Los Angeles and opened his own barber shop in Laguna Beach. A few years later he volunteered for service in the Abraham Lincoln battalion in Spain, and upon returning to California , he joined a life drawing group. He attended the California School of Fine Arts in San Francisco in 1940, studying with William Gaw and Spencer Macky, and in 1945 had his first major solo exhibition. At this time he also won the San Francisco Art Association's Albert Bender Memorial Prize. In 1946 he studied at the Art Students' League in New York and traveled to Mexico. He received much press when one of his paintings was removed from an exhibition at the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum for obscenity in 1950. Despite this setback, he continued to regularly exhibition his work over the next decade.

A renewed interest in Irving Norman's work occurred in the mid-1970s, at which time he exhibited many new paintings. During the 1980s he continued to exhibit his work and participated in several video interviews. In 1988 a storm caused a fire which destroyed his house and studio, including drawings and most personal papers. Irving Norman passed away at home in July 1989 and a memorial retrospective of his work was held at San Jose State University the following year. Hela Norman continued to manage the sale and exhibition of Irving's artwork until her death in 2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is biographical material belonging to Irving and Hela Norman, including citizenship, marriage, and death records, wills, and identification documents. Also found are documents regarding Irving Norman's activities, such as drafts of a biographical chronology and related notes, records of his participation in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, and photocopies and correspondence regarding his FBI file. Also of note are some photocopies of early records and photographs which were sent to Hela from a family member.

did.unittitle: Last Will and Testament of Irving Noachowitz (Norman)
Last Will and Testament of Hela Noachowitz (Norman)
Lists of Collectors and Public Collections
Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most correspondence consists of letters between Hela Norman and others concerning the works of Irving Norman, and post-dates his death. Included is extensive correspondence from 1989, the year of his death. Correspondence is with curators, museums, galleries, art dealers, friends, and family. Of note is extensive correspondence with curators Michael Bell and Patricia Junker; and friends Daniel Gundlach, Jerry Freeman, Judith Freeman, and Martin Sosin. Additionally there are many letters from Irving Norman's daughter, Maxine Ferriera, some of which contain biographical information. Researchers should note that letters from the same individuals may be found within the alphabetical and chronological correspondence. Most of the correspondence dated before 1975 are photocopies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as 2 subseries.

did.unittitle: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are many audio and video recordings of interviews with Irving and Hela Norman. Interviews were conducted for television programs as well as documentary projects. Of note are extensive interviews conducted at the Norman's home by Daniel Gundlach, an interview conducted by Oscar Lemer after the Norman's house and studio fire, and recordings for the short documentary by Susan Friedman, "Irving Norman: To Whom it May Concern." In addition to the original videocassette or sound cassette recordings, most interviews include digital copies on CD or DVD, and were transcribed in 2008. Some interviews also include additional cassettes containing selected excerpts. Additional documentation regarding these interviews may be found within the correspondence in Series 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The scattered writings found here include notes written by Hela Norman, a brief biography of Hela, and hand-written recollections of Irving Norman by his daughter, Maxine Ferriera. Also found are a few essays about Irving Norman's work.

did.unittitle: Maria Beeler, "From War to Gardens: A Biography of Hela Norman"
Joseph M. Lugo, "A Poem to You/In Light of Your Vision"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exhibition records consist of files documenting several retrospective exhibitions of Irving Norman's work. These files may include correspondence, notes, press clippings, exhibition publications, price lists, loan forms, planning documents, and draft catalog essays. Also found is a chronological set of exhibition press compiled by Hela Norman.

did.unittitle: "The Measure of All Things: Paintings by Irving Norman," M. H. deYoung Memorial Museum (July 3-October 6, 1996)
"Irving Norman: Social Realist," Mary Porter Sesnon Art Gallery (January 9-February 23, 1996)
"The Art of War and Peace," American Visionary Art Museum (October 6, 2001-September 1, 2002)
"On Being Human: The Social Surrealist Paintings of Irving Norman," Santa Monica College (October 5-November 1, 2002)
Touring Exhibition, "Dark Metropolis: Irving Norman's Social Surrealism"
Exhibitions at Nora Eccles Harrison Museum of Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are personal business records, including lists of artworks and documents regarding artwork appraisal, conservation, gifts, and photography. Also found is a bound index to Irving Norman's artwork which includes notations on what was lost in the 1988 studio fire. Additionally there are book project documents for Dark Metropolis: Irving Norman's Social Surrealism (2006), published by Heyday Books. Business dealings with several art galleries include correspondence, consignment and sales records, printed material, and price lists.

did.unittitle: Gift to Art Institute of Chicago
Gift to Vilna Gaon Jewish State Museum
Sale to Oakland Museum of California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The small amount of printed material in this collection includes news clipping about the Normans, a few announcements for exhibitions of Irving Norman's work, and blank notecards that he designed. Additional printed material can be found within the exhibition records in Series 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs depict Irving Norman as a young adult, later in life with his wife Hela, and posing with his paintings. Also found is one photograph of him with fellow artist Charles Ware. Additionally there are photographs of Irving Norman's funeral, and early family photographs. Color photographs of Norman's artwork provide a nearly complete inventory of his paintings and are arranged chronologically. Many of the photographs are labeled with title, date, and current owner. The last three folders of photographs in this series are only available digitally and do not include paper prints.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Irving and Hela Norman

did.physdesc: Includes 8 electronic discs (CD) and 1 hard drive
